Units.UnitGuidingQuestion: Have you ever tried to share with your friends in a way that is fair? In this unit, you will learn how to divide things so that everyone gets an equal share. You will learn about a new operation called division. You will also learn about other uses for division.
Units.UnitOverview:
Type of Unit: Conceptual

Length (in days): 15 days

Prior Knowledge

  • Fluency with all products through
  • Knowledge that the multiplier counts the number of groups, and the multiplicand counts the number of objects in a group
  • Recognition of equal groups situations as multiplication situations


Lesson Flow
This unit introduces students to division. Multiplication and division are inverse operations;
if a x b = c then c / a = b. In a division situation, there is some total quantity that is to be distributed equally. There are two types of division situations:
  • Division to find the number of objects in each group, called partitive or sharing division. In sharing situations, the number of groups is known, and division is used to find the size of each group.
  • Division to find the number of groups, called quotitive or grouping division. In measurement situations, the size of the groups is known and division is used to find the number of groups.

Lessons.LessonName: How Long Will Each Piece Be?

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion:
Your Grade 3 math adventure starts here! It will be a year of exploring equal-sized group situations, two-dimensional shapes, and fractions.

In this unit, you will get acquainted with your tablet, understand how this math class will work, learn your responsibilities for the class time, and explore place value.

Show the time on an analog clock and tell time to the hour and minute. Solve math stories about elapsed time using a timeline. Use what you know about solving addition and subtraction stories to solve math stories about time. Complete a card sort to show an elapsed time math story.

You will deepen your understanding of using graphs to display data. In grade 2 you learned about picture graphs, bar graphs, and line plots. In this unit, you will learn about how to use scales with intervals greater than 1 to display larger sets of data on picture graphs and bar graphs. You will create a line plot of data from your class. You will work on a graphing data project of your choice with a partner and present the project to your class.

Why do we need standard units of measure? What standard units can we use to measure weight and volume?

You will experience measuring volume in milliliters and liters using a liter cube. And solve word problems involving measuring volume.

You will investigate and compare the weights of common objects and solve word problems involving measuring weight in grams and kilograms.

First you will explore patterns in addition. You will use these patterns to help you understand a strategy for addition and a strategy for subtraction. You will also look at the patterns for the turn-arounds for the addition facts. Next you will learn how to round numbers to the nearest hundred and the nearest ten. You will then explore strategies for adding and subtracting numbers with three digits. You will also learn how to subtract a number from 1,000.

First you find different ways to count the number of fingers in your class. The next two days, you will look at multiplication facts with 5. The first day you will look at patterns of multiplication and the answers, and the next day you will be reciting chants to help memorize these facts and illustrating multiplication stories. The next lessons, you will repeat the process with facts involving 2, 3, and 4.

Explore quadrilaterals and their characteristics: rectangles, squares, and rhombuses. Learn why a square is a rectangle and a rhombus. Calculate the perimeter of rectangles and rhombuses. Then combine different figures to form different types of quadrilaterals.

Multiplying is all about patterns and repeated addition. In this unit, you will combine different patterns and discover ways of thinking about multiplication. Memorizing basic facts can be fun when learned through chants, clapping, snapping, and tapping. Creating and solving story problems for others to investigate is like putting together a puzzle and can be exciting! You will enjoy these and many more fun and challenging multiplication activities.

Start with a card sort that gives you a chance to recall and solidify your understanding of multiplication properties. Next, write rules for multiplying 1 and 10, and focus on multiples of 10. Play a penny toss game to understand that the product of any number and 0 is 0. Practice and master your multiplication facts up to 10.

This unit is all about fractions! You will divide a whole into equal parts and find what fraction 1 part is of the whole—known as a unit fraction. You will represent unit fractions and fractions greater than 1 using area models and number lines. You will learn that unit fractions make up all fractions that are more than 1 equal part of a whole. You will compare fractions with the same numerator.

Lessons.LessonName: Parts of One Piece of Clay
Greater Than or Equal to One

Units.UnitGuidingQuestion: In this unit, you will learn about area. You will measure area and compare areas of figures. You will develop ways to find the areas of rectangles and other figures. Finally, you will investigate perimeters of figures with equal areas, and areas of figures with equal perimeters.

Learning how to find an unknown number is like solving a mystery, finding a treasure on a treasure hunt, or answering a riddle. In this unit you'll use skills you know already, and learn some new ones that will help you solve real-world problems. You will estimate, solve, and check the answers to math stories involving addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. In some equations, you will use a letter, or variable, to represent the unknown numbers that you are trying to find.

Lessons.LessonName: A Day at Dolores Huerta Elementary School
